References.Title: A study of the effects of the use of vertical reading ability groupings for reading classes as compared with heterogeneous groupings in grades four, five, and six in the Port Huron Area Schools of Michigan over a three-year period.
References.Abstract: The problem concerning the improvement of reading instruction at the later elementary level was defined for the research study as follows: Will the use of vertical ability grouping over a three-year period in reading classes for grades four, five, and six in the Port Huron Area Schools of Michigan result in significantly different achievement for those groups as compared to classes grouped heterogeneously? The research design was established in three parts: I. A One-Year study of a Ten Percent Random sample from an experimental group of 1200 students in grades 4, 5, and 6 grouped vertically for reading, matched according to intelligence quotient, grade level, sex, and reading grade score with an equal number of students from a control group of 690 students grouped heterogeneously according to regular grade level. II. A Four-Year Cross-Sectional Comparison of intelligence quotient and reading scores of sixth-grade students during the two years prior to the grouping experiment and the first two years of the experiment. III. A Three-Year ten longitudinal Comparison of the reading test records of 100 students who were enrolled in the experimental reading program in grades 4, 5, and 6. Results are reported and discussed.
References.Comments: CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is a scanned file and too large to upload. Please contact the team if you would like access to this. *ES coding. Please use spreadsheet to combine results for grades 4, 5 & 6 comparing the experimental vs. control group.
References.QuickCitation: DeGrow G S (1964) A study of the effects of the use of vertical reading ability groupings for reading classes as compared with heterogeneous groupings in grades four, five, and six in the Port Huron Area Schools of Michigan over a three-year period.. , .

References.Title: Peer effects, teacher incentives, and the impact of tracking: Evidence from a randomized evaluation in Kenya
References.Abstract: To the extent that students benefit from high-achieving peers, tracking will help strong students and hurt weak ones. However, all students may benefit if tracking allows teachers to better tailor their instruction level. Lower-achieving pupils are particularly likely to benefit from tracking when teachers have incentives to teach to the top of the distribution. We propose a simple model nesting these effects and test its implications in a randomized tracking experiment conducted with 121 primary schools in Kenya. While the direct effect of high-achieving peers is positive, tracking benefited lower-achieving pupils indirectly by allowing teachers to teach to their level.
References.Comments: ESDE: Please focus in coding data for Total score-short term.
References.Authors: Duflo E ; Dupas P ; Kremer M ;
References.QuickCitation: Duflo E, Dupas P, and Kremer M (2011) Peer effects, teacher incentives, and the impact of tracking: Evidence from a randomized evaluation in Kenya. American Economic Review 101(5), 1739-1774 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1257/aer.101.5.1739

References.Title: The Effect Of Grouping On Achievement And Attitudes Toward Learning Of First Grade Pupils
References.Abstract: This experimental study dealt with two approaches to grouping first grade pupils for instruction. Specifically, the study sought to determine whether there was any significant difference in reading achievement, arithmetic achievement and attitudes toward learning between children who were grouped by ability and those who were randomly assigned to classes. Four of seventeen first grade classes in a suburban school district were designated as "high," "middle" or "low." Each pupil in the school which housed the homogeneously grouped classes was assigned to the appropriate class on the basis of the kindergarten teacher's judgment of his potential academic success. This teacher judgment was made by predicting whether the child would be in the upper quarter, middle one-half, or lower quarter of his first grade class as regards success in reading and arithmetic. There was no attempt to differentiate among the pupils in the middle 50 per cent and thus there were two "middle" classes, one "high" class, and one "low" class. The pupils in the heterogeneously grouped classes received their class assignments by being randomly placed in one of four or five first grade classes in the building designated by the regular school district boundaries. Kindergarten teacher predictions of pupil performance were also available on this group. A total of approximately four hundred seventy-five children were involved in the study with one hundred fifteen pupils assigned to the homogeneous classes. The criteria measures selected for evaluation were reading achievement, arithmetic achievement and attitudes toward learning. Information regarding chronological age, readiness test scores, intelligence test results and teacher judgment comprised available independent variable data. In addition, measures of teacher attitudes, the social structure of the class group and the emotional climate of the classroom were gathered as potential covariates. Major findings of the study were: 1) F ratios obtained from the analysis of variance indicate a significant difference in favor of homogeneous grouping in the high ability group. This portion of the analysis did not take cognizance of the covariates. 2) Emotional climate of the classroom and the social structure of the class group were found to provide significant covariate data. 3) Inclusion of the covariate data in the multivariate analysis continued to support the value of homogeneous grouping, though the analysis points up the significance of this difference as being in the middle and low ability groups when the covariate effects are taken into account.
References.Comments: Please focus on coding the homogeneous vs. the heterogeneous groups for total reading and total arithmetic scores. This is for the setting or streaming Toolkit strand, so homogeneous groups (setting) are the intervention and heterogeneous groups (mixed attainment) are the control.
References.QuickCitation: Flair Merrel Dean (1964) The Effect Of Grouping On Achievement And Attitudes Toward Learning Of First Grade Pupils. , Northwestern University.

References.Title: Abilitygrouping in Secondary Schools and Attainment
References.Abstract: Of course, when the Secretaries of State (DES, 1977) wrote the above they had in mind the selection of children to go to a particular type of school, and in this narrow context the statement is true. However, the importance of this change could be illusory if divisions between schools have merely been replaced by selective systems within the schools. Downey & Kelly (1975), for example, have argued that comprehensive education cannot" be undertaken without fundamental re-appraisal of the internal reorganization of the school.

References.Title: Interclass Grouping for Reading Instruction in the Middle Grades
References.Abstract: THE JOPLIN PLAN (2) is an administrative device for reducing the heterogeneity in reading skill of a group during instruction in reading. A reading period is set aside for pupils in, say, grades 4, 5, and 6, during which these students leave their regular classes and join others in these grades whose reading level is approximately comparable to their own. Thus greater homogeneity in reading skill is attained in each group than is generally found within class groupings. Presumably greater diversity in all other areas also results. Starting in 1957 a number of schools in Atlanta decided to give the Joplin plan a try. The faculty of each school made the decision independently and implemented it in their own fashion. Four of these schools (hereafter Schools A, B, C, and D) believed to serve a representative cross section of the white population of the city* were selected for study. The experimental procedures followed in each school will be described below. For various reasons complete data for all the grades considered could not be obtained from all four schools. School A was able to supply datafor grades 4 and 6 but not for grade 5; for Schools B and D, 6th-grade data were incomplete but ade quate information about grades 4 and 5 were obtained; only the 4th grade of School C could be in cluded. Control group data were obtained from the re cords of pupils in these schools and grades for the year prior to the inauguration of the experimental program. Schools A and B first tried the plan in 1958-59. Schools C and D began the preceding year. The experimental group subjects were I drawn from those pupils in the appropriate grades I in 1958-59.
References.Comments: Please code Grade 4.
References.Authors: Green Donald Ross; Riley Hazel Walker;
References.QuickCitation: Green Donald Ross, and Riley Hazel Walker (1963) Interclass Grouping for Reading Instruction in the Middle Grades. The Journal of Experimental Education 31(3), 273-278 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220973.1963.11010775

References.Title: Interclass Grouping for Reading Instruction in the Middle Grades
References.Abstract: THE JOPLIN PLAN (2) is an administrative device for reducing the heterogeneity in reading skill of a group during instruction in reading. A reading period is set aside for pupils in, say, grades 4, 5, and 6, during which these students leave their regular classes and join others in these grades whose reading level is approximately comparable to their own. Thus greater homogeneity in reading skill is attained in each group than is generally found within class groupings. Presumably greater diversity in all other areas also results. Starting in 1957 a number of schools in Atlanta decided to give the Joplin plan a try. The faculty of each school made the decision independently and implemented it in their own fashion. Four of these schools (hereafter Schools A, B, C, and D) believed to serve a representative cross section of the white population of the city* were selected for study. The experimental procedures followed in each school will be described below. For various reasons complete data for all the grades considered could not be obtained from all four schools. School A was able to supply datafor grades 4 and 6 but not for grade 5; for Schools B and D, 6th-grade data were incomplete but ade quate information about grades 4 and 5 were obtained; only the 4th grade of School C could be in cluded. Control group data were obtained from the re cords of pupils in these schools and grades for the year prior to the inauguration of the experimental program. Schools A and B first tried the plan in 1958-59. Schools C and D began the preceding year. The experimental group subjects were I drawn from those pupils in the appropriate grades I in 1958-59.
References.Comments: Please code Grade 5.
References.Authors: Green Donald Ross; Riley Hazel Walker;
References.QuickCitation: Green Donald Ross, and Riley Hazel Walker (1963) Interclass Grouping for Reading Instruction in the Middle Grades. The Journal of Experimental Education 31(3), 273-278 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220973.1963.11010775

References.Title: A Comparison of Pupil Achievement in Graded and Nongraded Primary Classrooms
References.Abstract: The past decade will stand out for educators as a period of marked ferment in education. Although most of the ferment has taken place at the secondary school level, the elementary schools have also been affected greatly. While several noteworthy experimental programs featuring the teaching of foreign languages, the utilizing of an individualized reading program and the adopting of new approaches to the teaching of mathematics in the elementary schools have been undertaken. It was the purpose of this study to determine whether there would be a significant gain in the achievement of primary grade pupils after a variation of the nongraded primary unit was adopted. More specifically, the investigation sought to compare the achievement of 146 primary pupils who had been taught for approximately one year under a nongraded program in reading and spelling with the achievement of 149 primary pupils who had been taught solely within the framework of the graded class structure.
References.Comments: CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is available to download and for checking, it does not display correctly for highlighting. Main DE: Non-grading is cross -age ability (homogeneous) grouping - same age is mixed ability (heterogeneous) grouping. This is a retrospective natural experiment in one school.ESDE: Extract year groups (Grades) separately CAT Reading comprehension as primary in Grade 1. Use means and SDs post-test only. Extract other outcomes as secondaries.
References.QuickCitation: Halliwell Joseph W (1963) A Comparison of Pupil Achievement in Graded and Nongraded Primary Classrooms. The Journal of Experimental Education 32(1), 59-64 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220973.1963.11010808

References.Title: A Comparison of Pupil Achievement in Graded and Nongraded Primary Classrooms
References.Abstract: The past decade will stand out for educators as a period of marked ferment in education. Although most of the ferment has taken place at the secondary school level, the elementary schools have also been affected greatly. While several noteworthy experimental programs featuring the teaching of foreign languages, the utilizing of an individualized reading program and the adopting of new approaches to the teaching of mathematics in the elementary schools have been undertaken. It was the purpose of this study to determine whether there would be a significant gain in the achievement of primary grade pupils after a variation of the nongraded primary unit was adopted. More specifically, the investigation sought to compare the achievement of 146 primary pupils who had been taught for approximately one year under a nongraded program in reading and spelling with the achievement of 149 primary pupils who had been taught solely within the framework of the graded class structure.
References.Comments: CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is available to download and for checking, it does not display correctly for highlighting. Main DE: Non-grading is cross-age ability (homogeneous) grouping - same age is mixed ability (heterogeneous) grouping. This is a retrospective natural experiment in one school.ESDE: ESDE: Extract MAT Reading as primary for Grade 3. Use means and SDs post-test only. Extract other outcomes as secondaries.
References.QuickCitation: Halliwell Joseph W (1963) A Comparison of Pupil Achievement in Graded and Nongraded Primary Classrooms. The Journal of Experimental Education 32(1), 59-64 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220973.1963.11010808

References.Title: The Effectiveness of an Approach to the Problem of Varying Abilities in Teaching Reading
References.Abstract: The problem of providing for the needs of pupils of varying ability has long challenged the resourceful and conscientious teacher. In the field of language arts in the elementary school, the grouping of children within a classroom as the means of adjusting the instructional program to the needs of the pupils has been utilized with success. Such a developmental program had been in effect at Peter Boscow School for a number of years. Each teacher had at least three groups in reading. Each group was reading in a developmental basal text. It was thought desirable to test, as part of an evaluation of the above program, the following hypothesis : Children's achievement in reading will be significantly greater in a reading instructional program where pupils are grouped homogeneously according to ability than in a heterogeneous. The results of this experiment indicate that reading achievement under the experimental program was significantly greater than the reading achievement under the regular program. All other factors being equal, it is this writer's opinion that this study gives strong support to those teachers and administrators who believe that ability grouping.
References.Comments: Please code fourth to fifth grade.
References.QuickCitation: Hart Richard H (1959) The Effectiveness of an Approach to the Problem of Varying Abilities in Teaching Reading. The Journal of Educational Research 52(6), 228-231 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220671.1959.10882571

[s]"This coding process identified two general types of ability-grouped schools: those using two levels and those using three. Two of the schools used four groups in science and nine used four groups in mathematics. For present purposes, the two-group and four-group structures are recorded into a common three-"
"level scheme. Most of the four-level schools distinguished two "below grade-level" groups, an "average" group, and one "ad vanced" group. In all of these cases, one of the two low groups enrolled only a few of the sampled students, and the two groups were thus collapsed into a single low group. Two of the four-level schools, however, distin guished two advanced groups, and these were collapsed into a single high level. Vir tually all of the two-group schools distin guished a relatively small advanced group from a relatively large average group, and these were mapped onto the three-level scheme as "high" and "middle" with no low group. A few schools went the other way, defining a small low group and a large mid dle group; these were coded as "low" and "middle."[e]"

References.Title: Middle School Ability Grouping and Student Achievement in Science and Mathematics
References.Publisher: SAGE PublicationsSage CA: Los Angeles, CA
References.Abstract: This paper analyzes the effects of middle school ability grouping on cognitive achievement in mathematics and science. In contrast to most previous research on tracking, this analysis compares outcomes in grouped and non-grouped schools. The hypotheses tested here are, first, that ability grouping raises the aggregate level of student achievement and, second, that ability grouping achieves this end by increasing the learning of all students. Comparing average student achievement growth from the seventh to the ninth grades in grouped and non-grouped schools shows that overall gains from ability grouping in either subject are negligible, controlling for differences in student social background and initial levels of achievement. Comparing the achievement growth of non-grouped students and high- and low-group students shows that high-group placement generally has a weak positive effect while low-group placement has a stronger negative effect. Ability grouping thus appears to benefit advanced students, to harm slower students, and to have a negligible overall effect as the benefits and liabilities cancel each other.
References.QuickCitation: Hoffer Thomas B (1991) Middle School Ability Grouping and Student Achievement in Science and Mathematics. Educational Evaluation and Policy Analysis 14(3), 205-227 DOI: https://doi.org/10.3102/01623737014003205

References.Title: Flint Evaluates Its Primary Cycle
References.Abstract: Children grouped in three age group blocks from the end of Kindergarten called the 'Primary Cycle". Non-graded lessons took place for reading, language arts and social studies, but regrouped for other classes. The scores of 68 children who had completed all three years in the Primary Cycle were compared with the scores of 337 children who had completed third grade at Washington School in 1956, in 1957, and in 1958.
References.QuickCitation: Ingram Vivien (1960) Flint Evaluates Its Primary Cycle. The Elementary School Journal 61(2), 76-80 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1086/459860

Page 1:
[s]"Pupils in both experimental and control groups were initially assigned to one of three reading levels upon their entrance into first grade. However, for the experimental group the distinction between first and second grade was eliminated at the end of the first year. Three additional reading levels were created and a pupil in his second year of school could be in any one of the six existing reading levels, depending upon his progress. At the end of the second year the designation of third grade was abandoned and another three reading levels created. Pupils in the experimental group, regardless of their rate of progress, began reading instruction each fall at the point where they had finished the previous year. Grade designations were retained for the control group and pupils could move only within the three reading levels for their grade. Except for those classified as failures, all pupils in the control group moved on to the next grade[e]"

References.Title: A Comparison of Pupil Achievement after One and One-Half and Three Years in a Nongraded Program
References.Abstract: Effects of nongraded organization on reading performance of elementary pupils were assessed at the end of one and one-half school years and three years to determine If non-grading resulted in differences in performance, and if differences were stable after nongrading became an established part of the school organization. Teachers (N = 0) and pupils (N = 52) were randomly assigned to E (nungraded) and C (graded) groups. Teachers of both groups received Identical treatment: workshops, consultant services, and materials. Reading performance of 13 group was significantly higher (p .01) at end of eighteen months, but there were no significant differences at end of three years. Differences in results may be due to transient effects of experimental conditions or greater suitability of nongraded organisation for beginning students.
References.Comments: CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is available to download and for checking, it does not display correctly for highlighting. Main DE: Ability grouping (non-graded) versus mixed ability (graded) classrooms, over 3 years.ESDE: Use t-test values for experimental (ability grouping) versus control (mixed ability) with CAT Reading as primary and CAT Paragraph and Word subscales as secondaries at end of 3 years.
References.Authors: Jones Charles ; Moore William ; Devender Frank Van;
References.QuickCitation: Jones Charles, Moore William, and Devender Frank Van (1967) A Comparison of Pupil Achievement after One and One-Half and Three Years in a Nongraded Program. The Journal of Educational Research 61(2), 75-77 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220671.1967.10883590

References.Title: A longitudinal study of the effectiveness of the track plan in the secondary schools of a metropolitan community
References.Abstract: Four schools were selected with a total sample of 798 students (364 control and 434 experimental), comparing tracked and untracked classes across ten currlculum areas using Iowa Test of Educational development. ANOVA was used to ascertain significant differences in achievement between the control and experimental tracks. The analysis yielded overall non-significant results.
References.Comments:
CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is a scanned file and too large to upload. The OCR version is poor. Please contact the team if you would like access to the scan, it is too large to upload. 
Main DE: This study is for the Toolkit strand 'Setting or Streaming' (Within and Between class grouping). Please focus on the tracked group as the intervention.
ESDE: The effects size can be calculated from Tables 11 and 14 (Iowa test of Basic Skills and curriculum subjects respectively). Please use the Iowa composite score as the primary outcome and then please also extract the subject outcomes for English, Social Studies, Science and Mathematics (1-4) from Table 14. To find the SD for each test, please use the square root of the variance.
References.QuickCitation: Kline RE (1963) A longitudinal study of the effectiveness of the track plan in the secondary schools of a metropolitan community. , .

[s]"eously and followed a regular course of study.
During the 1959-1960 school session, pupils
in five fourth-grade classes at Deep Creek Ele
mentary School participated in the study as ex
perimental subjects. Control subjects were se
lected from the fourth grades of two other Norfolk
County Schools.
At the close of the third grade, experimental
and control pupils were given the Iowa Tests of
Basic Skills. Grouping of experimental classes
for fourth-grade study was effected through the
use of scores from this test. Homogeneous
groups were formed in three areas: arithmetic,
language, andreading. All experimental pupils
I were listed in rank order in terms of their grade
equivalent scores. The members of a class were
chosen then by selecting the top 20 percent, the
second 20 percent, and so on. Pupils were placed
in arithmetic class on the basis of their arithme
tic scores, in language class on the basis of their
language scores, and in reading class on the ba
sis of their reading scores. Some pupils who
were in the highest reading class were only aver
age in arithmetic; therefore, they would be in a
lower arithmetic class. As a result, it was ne
cessary for these pupils to change classes for
study in the three areas mentioned. For study in
areas other than arithmetic, language, and read
ing, the groups remained intact and did not change
classes.
At the beginning of the fourth grade, it was
found that one experimental class, on the aver
age, was achieving at the fifth-grade level; there
fore, fifth-grade materials were provided. Two
classes were given fourth-grade materials and
two classes were given third-grade materials be
cause of their levels of achievement[e]"

References.Title: A Study of Achievement as a Function of Homogeneous Grouping
References.Abstract: Early attempts at class grouping were executed with no empirical proof of its efficacy; and even today, there is inconclusive evidence as to the instructional value of homogeneous grouping. Approximately 25 years ago, it was reported that the literature related to homogeneous grouping had been carefully reviewed, and the most significant conclusion from it all was how little it had brought of clearly incontestable knowledge"(3). Professor Passow, in 1956, stated that there was no" significant unanimity of findings" in this area. The purpose of this study w as to test the null hypothesis that children grouped homogeneously by subject matter achievement, and who were given instructional materials on their achievement level, would show no greater achievement as a result than pupils who were grouped heterogeneously. On the basis of the evidence gathered in this study, this hypothesis cannot be rejected. Here, too, as in many other studies, homogeneous grouping failed to realize its theoretical possibilities. Experimental and control pupils were closely matched in terms of achievement at the beginning of the experiment. However, it may be that many variables that need to be controlled in experimentation with human behavior evaded control in this study.
References.QuickCitation: Koontz William F (1961) A Study of Achievement as a Function of Homogeneous Grouping. The Journal of Experimental Education 30(2), 249-253 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220973.1961.11010712

References.Title: Evaluation Of A Vertical-Horizontal Enrichment Program For The Math-Gifted Students Fourth, Fifth And Sixth Grades.
References.Abstract:
In an attempt to determine and organize an effective mathematics program for the most capable students in mathematics, Pasadena Unified School District designed a vertical-horizontal enrichment program. In this study the vertical-horizontal enrichment program was set up by combining the techniques of homogeneous grouping and providing differentiation of assignments through enriched curriculum opportunities. The purpose of this study was to determine if a significant difference existed in arithmetic achievement and in attitude toward arithmetic among
mathematically-gifted students who participated in a vertical-horizontal program and similarly mathematically gifted students who did not receive such instruction. The 121 students in the experimental schools participated in a vertical-horizontal enrichment program in three elementary schools and the 94 students in the three control schools did not receive such instruction. Significantly greater gains were made on the CTBS by the fourth graders in the experimental group than in the control group both in arithmetic computation and total arithmetic (P <.04 and P ^ .005). There were no significant differences between the treatment groups in gains in the Concepts and Application subtests. No significant differences existed between the treatment groups in any of the subtests of the CTBS at the fifth grade level. Negative adjusted gains were obtained in the raw scores with regard to all the subtests. In the analysis involving arithmetic achievement on the CTBS for the sixth grade, both groups showed gains with the means of the experimental group being higher as compared to the control group, but none of the means reached levels of significance.
References.Comments: ESDE: This study has been duplicated to extract for grades 4, 5 and 6 separately.Please focus on extracting data for grade 4 only for this data extraction. Use raw scores for CTBS Computation, Concepts and Application using f-values in Appendix. Please extract Group post-test only (9 outcomes) and Group Gain (unadjusted) (another 9 outcomes).
References.QuickCitation: Koukeyan Berjouhi B (1976) Evaluation Of A Vertical-Horizontal Enrichment Program For The Math-Gifted Students Fourth, Fifth And Sixth Grades.. , Brigham Young University.

Use raw scores for CTBS Computation, Concepts and Application using f-values in Appendix. Please extract Group post-test only (9 outcomes) and Group Gain (unadjusted) (another 9 outcomes).

References.Title: Ability Grouping And Its Effect Upon Individual Achievement
References.Abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate one specific type of homogeneous grouping. The grouping procedure employed in this investigation centered around careful consideration of such factors as intelligence quotient, mental age, chronological age, reading achievement level, composite rating of a standardized basic skills test, teacher appraisal of ability, sex, and the school administrator's judgment. Each pupil in grades four, five, and six was categorized as belonging to one of five ability levels designated bright, above average, average, below average, and low by the principals, teachers, and the writer. In schools where there was more than one section per grade these levels were used as the basis for sectioning. In one class section were placed all pupils, of a specific grade, who were identified as belonging to the bright ability level. In another section, separate from the one containing the bright pupils, the pupils identified as belonging to the low ability class were placed. Grouped along with the bright ability level pupils were other students of the same grade who were identified as belonging to the ability levels designated as above average, average, and below average.  The results of this analysis verified that all heterogeneous classes encompassed pupils from all five ability levels. For each pupil in the study the following information was collected: a) IQ; b) Grade; c ) Age; d) Mental Age; f ) Iowa Tests of Basic Skills for all areas of the test ( i.e. Vocabulary, Reading, Language, Work Study, Arithmetic , and Composite.) This study devoted itself to the overall group comparisons between those students in the homogeneous and heterogeneous classes who were identified as belonging to the same ability levels. To test the significance between all group comparisons the F statistic using analysis of variance procedures was employed. The results, in general, do not lend support to the claimed advantage of grouping as opposed to no grouping. The evidence presented seems to indicate that pupils, for the most part, are not affected by the administrative procedure commonly described as homogeneous grouping. The fact that the homogeneous classes did not achieve significantly more than did the heterogeneous classes does not automatically rule out any advantages to the grouping procedure. It may well be that the instructional task was made easier by having the extremely bright in one room and the extremely low in another room. The evidence presented in this study indicates no decided advantage of this method of grouping over a random method of assigning pupils to classes. The evidence seems to indicate that grouping is merely an administrative device employed to serve the schools in assigning pupils to classes. If there are advantages accruing to this procedure, they must be found in areas other than those measurable by a standardized test of basic skills. The key to good education of children evidently rests with good teaching. This study points this out by showing that the grouping procedure does not by and in itself produce greater gains by students, at least those in grades four, five, and six.
References.Comments: This study has three different grades; 4, 5, 6, different ability levels and 2 groups; homogeneous vs. heterogeneous. Please focus in coding tables 7 and 8. Please code grade 4 homogeneous high vs. heterogeneous bright composite score.
References.QuickCitation: Loomer Bradley Max A X (1962) Ability Grouping And Its Effect Upon Individual Achievement. , .

Outcomes.Title: LOW_ITBS Grade 4 Hom Low v Het Low
Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: Iowa Test for Basic Skills Grade 4 Hom Low V Het Low Composite

References.Title: Ability Grouping And Its Effect Upon Individual Achievement
References.Abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate one specific type of homogeneous grouping. The grouping procedure employed in this investigation centered around careful consideration of such factors as intelligence quotient, mental age, chronological age, reading achievement level, composite rating of a standardized basic skills test, teacher appraisal of ability, sex, and the school administrator's judgment. Each pupil in grades four, five, and six was categorized as belonging to one of five ability levels designated bright, above average, average, below average, and low by the principals, teachers, and the writer. In schools where there was more than one section per grade these levels were used as the basis for sectioning. In one class section were placed all pupils, of a specific grade, who were identified as belonging to the bright ability level. In another section, separate from the one containing the bright pupils, the pupils identified as belonging to the low ability class were placed. Grouped along with the bright ability level pupils were other students of the same grade who were identified as belonging to the ability levels designated as above average, average, and below average.  The results of this analysis verified that all heterogeneous classes encompassed pupils from all five ability levels. For each pupil in the study the following information was collected: a) IQ; b) Grade; c ) Age; d) Mental Age; f ) Iowa Tests of Basic Skills for all areas of the test ( i.e. Vocabulary, Reading, Language, Work Study, Arithmetic , and Composite.) This study devoted itself to the overall group comparisons between those students in the homogeneous and heterogeneous classes who were identified as belonging to the same ability levels. To test the significance between all group comparisons the F statistic using analysis of variance procedures was employed. The results, in general, do not lend support to the claimed advantage of grouping as opposed to no grouping. The evidence presented seems to indicate that pupils, for the most part, are not affected by the administrative procedure commonly described as homogeneous grouping. The fact that the homogeneous classes did not achieve significantly more than did the heterogeneous classes does not automatically rule out any advantages to the grouping procedure. It may well be that the instructional task was made easier by having the extremely bright in one room and the extremely low in another room. The evidence presented in this study indicates no decided advantage of this method of grouping over a random method of assigning pupils to classes. The evidence seems to indicate that grouping is merely an administrative device employed to serve the schools in assigning pupils to classes. If there are advantages accruing to this procedure, they must be found in areas other than those measurable by a standardized test of basic skills. The key to good education of children evidently rests with good teaching. This study points this out by showing that the grouping procedure does not by and in itself produce greater gains by students, at least those in grades four, five, and six.
References.Comments: This study has three different grades; 4, 5, 6, different ability levels and 2 groups; homogeneous vs. heterogeneous. Please focus in coding tables 7 and 8. Please code homogeneous low vs. heterogeneous low for grade 4 using the composite score.
References.QuickCitation: Loomer Bradley Max A X (1962) Ability Grouping And Its Effect Upon Individual Achievement. , .

Outcomes.Title: ALL_CrossAge_Reading Gain-G4 (Regrouping reading only)
Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: Gain in Reading Years from standardised tests not specified (Standardized reading tests were used to measure the reading level in grade equivalent of all pupils in the experiment) - Year 4 - Setting & streaming (Interclass grouping)

References.Title: Interclass Grouping for Reading Instruction
References.Abstract: During the first three years of elementary school, the range in reading level among pupils becomes wider and wider. It is common to find five to seven reading levels represented by the pupils in a fourth-grade class. In February, 1958, an experiment was begun in two public elementary schools of Laramie, Wyoming, to determine whether interclass grouping for reading in Grades 4, 5, and 6 would produce readers superior to those grouped conventionally by grade levels for reading. The experiment was evaluated at the end of one semester, at the end of three semesters, and again after five semesters.
References.Comments: Please code data for grade 4.CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is available to download and for checking, it does not display correctly for highlighting.
References.QuickCitation: Moorhouse William F (1964) Interclass Grouping for Reading Instruction. The Elementary School Journal 64(5), 280-286 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1086/460133

References.Title: Interclass Grouping for Reading Instruction
References.Abstract: During the first three years of elementary school, the range in reading level among pupils becomes wider and wider. It is common to find five to seven reading levels represented by the pupils in a fourth-grade class. In February, 1958, an experiment was begun in two public elementary schools of Laramie, Wyoming, to determine whether interclass grouping for reading in Grades 4, 5, and 6 would produce readers superior to those grouped conventionally by grade levels for reading. The experiment was evaluated at the end of one semester, at the end of three semesters, and again after five semesters.

References.Title: A Study Of The Effect Of Inter-Class Ability Grouping On Achievement In Reading
References.Institution: Louisiana State University and Agricultural & Mechanical College
References.Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to investigate the effect of inter-class ability grouping on the reading achievement of elementary students. Experimental and control classes were set up in grades four, five, and six in School District Twenty- Two of Calcasieu Parish. A total of twenty-seven experimental classes was established in the three grades. These twenty-seven classes consisted of nine each of high, average, and low ability levels. Four hundred fifty students, fifty at each ability level of each of the three grades, were selected at random from the experimental classes and paired with other students attending homogeneous classes in School District Twenty-Two. The students selected for the experimental classes were paired with other students in the same grade, according to sex, age, Stanford Achievement Reading Test scores, and California
Mental Maturity Test scores. Teachers for the different levels of the experimental groups were selected by lot from the teaching staff previously assigned to that particular school and grade. The same supervisory services and instructional materials were provided for the experimental and control groups. A second Stanford Achievement Test was administered at the end of the semester to all students used in the study. The results obtained from these tests were tabulated and the gains made in reading achievement were analyzed. The t-test was used to test for significance of the difference in mean grade placement gains in each group. The difference in mean gains was not found to be significant at the .05 level for any of the three ability levels. On the basis of the evidence presented.in this study, it is indicated that the reading achievement of elementary students is not significantly affected when inter-class ability grouping is practiced.
References.Comments: This study has 3 ability levels (A=high, B=average and C=low) (Please code group A test with Test 2 as the primary outcome (post-test only).
References.QuickCitation: Moses Paul James (1965) A Study Of The Effect Of Inter-Class Ability Grouping On Achievement In Reading. , Louisiana State University and Agricultural & Mechanical College.

References.Title: Intraclass grouping for reading instruction: Who Makes the Decisions and Why?
References.Abstract: The focus of this project was to compare the effectiveness of three methods of teaching reading to primary pupils. The data to be discussed were part of the data collected at the end of the second year of the study. The following unique situation occurred withing one of the three treatment groups. One of the cooperating schools had been using a plan of interclass grouping for reading instruction at first and second grade levels before the project began and continued the practice throughout the study. That is, pupils were randomly assigned to one of three homeroom classes. For reading instruction they were reassigned to one of the three teachers on the basis of readiness and of intelligence test scores. The superior pupils were assigned to one teacher, the average to another, and the below average to the third. The superior and below average groups participated in the Cooperative Research Project. At two other schools that were taking part in the project there were two other classrooms of children that almost exactly matched these two classes in terms of readiness and of intelligence measures. The pupils in these rooms had been randomly assigned to their class from the pool making up the several classes at that grade level. The achievement differences are overwhelmingly in favor of those pupils who were randomly assigned and received instruction in their own self-contained classroom. Their achievement actually equals that of the class identified as superior in the school with interclass ability grouping. The probability of the differences that are shown being due to measurement error is extremely small. Interclass grouping, with its alleged reduced range of variability and hence instructional needs, did not show any benefit for these below average pupils after two years of primary instruction.
References.QuickCitation: Nichols N (1969) Intraclass grouping for reading instruction: Who Makes the Decisions and Why?. Educational Leadership Research Supplement 26, 588-592

References.Title: The Effectiveness Of Ability Grouping In General Science Classes
References.Abstract: It was the purpose of this study (1) to compare the effect of ability grouping on the academic performance of ninth grade science students; and (2) to determine if a relationship exists between ability grouped and ungrouped students with regard to certain understandings, interests, and classroom performance in ninth grade science classes. Two hundred sixty-two students were grouped at three approximate levels: above average, with CTMM scores of 140-116; average, with CTM 4 scores of 115-96; and below average, with CTMM scores of 95-78. These students were then assigned to grouped and ungrouped classes and matched as nearly as possible according to eighth grade science marks, interest, age, and sex. The teacher variable was controlled by assigning each teacher five classes: two ability grouped, and three ungrouped. Academic achievement was measured by performance on the Discovery and Progress Science 3 Examination and by grades at the first and second marking periods. An attempt to discover whether the broad objectives of science were being met was made by gathering student responses to a questionnaire, and certain understandings regarding science were ascertained from data from the Test of Understanding Science distributed by the Educational Testing Service. Student classroom performance was measured by a teacher rating card. The data were treated using the t-score and chi square techniques and inferences were made on the basis of the statistical treatment. Based on the findings of this study 1. For increased student achievement on examinations, ability grouping of below-average students is more effective than the ungrouped system of classroom organization. Neither the grouped nor the ungrouped system of classroom organization is more effective for above-average and average students for the purpose of increased student achievement on examinations, nor is there any difference in the effectiveness of being grouped or ungrouped at any level where the purpose of grouping is student attainment of higher academic marks. 2. There is little relationship between being grouped and ungrouped in ninth grade general science and classroom performance, attendance, behavior, and citizenship as measured by teachers' ratings. Grouped systems of classroom organization may tend to result in more behavior problems than in ungrouped systems as noted by the number of guidance office referrals. 3. Student attitudes, interests, and understandings related to the broad objectives of general science are not influenced by types of classroom organization compared in this study. 4. There is little difference between being grouped or ungrouped when consideration is given to general science and certain understandings of science as measured by a standardized instrument.
References.Comments: This study has three group levels (above average, average, below average) and two marking periods. Please focus in coding grouped vs. ungrouped for the above average group having the 1st marking period as the primary outcome and the 2nd marking period as the secondary outcome.
References.QuickCitation: Platz Eugene Freeland (1965) The Effectiveness Of Ability Grouping In General Science Classes. , University of Southern California.

References.Title: The Effectiveness Of Ability Grouping In General Science Classes
References.Abstract: It was the purpose of this study (1) to compare the effect of ability grouping on the academic performance of ninth grade science students; and (2) to determine if a relationship exists between ability grouped and ungrouped students with regard to certain understandings, interests, and classroom performance in ninth grade science classes. Two hundred sixty-two students were grouped at three approximate levels: above average, with CTMM scores of 140-116; average, with CTM 4 scores of 115-96; and below average, with CTMM scores of 95-78. These students were then assigned to grouped and ungrouped classes and matched as nearly as possible according to eighth grade science marks, interest, age, and sex. The teacher variable was controlled by assigning each teacher five classes: two ability grouped, and three ungrouped. Academic achievement was measured by performance on the Discovery and Progress Science 3 Examination and by grades at the first and second marking periods. An attempt to discover whether the broad objectives of science were being met was made by gathering student responses to a questionnaire, and certain understandings regarding science were ascertained from data from the Test of Understanding Science distributed by the Educational Testing Service. Student classroom performance was measured by a teacher rating card. The data were treated using the t-score and chi square techniques and inferences were made on the basis of the statistical treatment. Based on the findings of this study 1. For increased student achievement on examinations, ability grouping of below-average students is more effective than the ungrouped system of classroom organization. Neither the grouped nor the ungrouped system of classroom organization is more effective for above-average and average students for the purpose of increased student achievement on examinations, nor is there any difference in the effectiveness of being grouped or ungrouped at any level where the purpose of grouping is student attainment of higher academic marks. 2. There is little relationship between being grouped and ungrouped in ninth grade general science and classroom performance, attendance, behavior, and citizenship as measured by teachers' ratings. Grouped systems of classroom organization may tend to result in more behavior problems than in ungrouped systems as noted by the number of guidance office referrals. 3. Student attitudes, interests, and understandings related to the broad objectives of general science are not influenced by types of classroom organization compared in this study. 4. There is little difference between being grouped or ungrouped when consideration is given to general science and certain understandings of science as measured by a standardized instrument.
References.Comments: This study has three group levels (above average, average, below average) and two marking periods. Please focus in coding grouped vs. ungrouped for the average group having the 1st marking period as the primary outcome and the 2nd marking period as the secondary outcome.
References.QuickCitation: Platz Eugene Freeland (1965) The Effectiveness Of Ability Grouping In General Science Classes. , .

References.Comments: This study has three group levels (above average, average, below average) and two marking periods. Please focus in coding grouped vs. ungrouped for the below average group having the 1st marking period as the primary outcome and the 2nd marking period as the secondary outcome.
References.QuickCitation: Platz Eugene Freeland (1965) The Effectiveness Of Ability Grouping In General Science Classes. , .

[s]"The Best Practice in Mixed Attainment (BPMA) intervention trained schools to adopt best practice mixed attainment approaches to grouping Year 7 and Year 8 students for English and mathematics in order to raise attainment. References.Title: Best Practice in Grouping Students Intervention B : Mixed Attainment Grouping Pilot report and executive summary
References.Abstract: The Best Practice in Mixed Attainment (BPMA) intervention trained schools to adopt best practice mixed attainment approaches to grouping Year 7 and Year 8 students for English and mathematics in order to raise attainment. Schools were expected to create classes that contained pupils with a wide range of Key Stage 2 national curriculum results in English and mathematics. Teachers were trained to communicate high expectations of all pupils and to use flexible within class grouping and differentiation techniques. They were asked to minimise the use of marks levels and grades, and to provide formative feedback through comments instead, with a view to creating a growth mindset in pupils. The intervention was developed by a team now based at UCL Institute of Education. The intervention was developed with three schools between September 2014 and July 2015 and piloted with a further eight intervention schools through a pilot randomised controlled trial (RCT) starting in September 2015 and following Year 7 students for two academic years. The trial was funded by the Education Endowment Foundation (EEF). The aim of the pilot trial was to help inform decisions about a future large-scale RCT and to identify barriers to adopting mixed ability teaching. Preliminary outcome data was collected in order to rehearse for a future trial.
References.Comments: NB School level analysis (aggregated data)
References.Authors: Roy Palak ; Styles Ben ; Walker Matt ; Bradshaw Sally ; Nelson Julie ;
References.QuickCitation: Roy Palak, Styles Ben, Walker Matt, Bradshaw Sally, and Nelson Julie (2018) Best Practice in Grouping Students Intervention B : Mixed Attainment Grouping Pilot report and executive summary. London: ,

References.Title: Inter-Class Grouping for Reading Instruction in the Intermediate Grades
References.Abstract: For some years the San Francisco Public Schools have used a system of grouping for reading instruction in the intermediate grades locally known as "circling." Instead of the more usual grouping within anyone class, "circling" means that a considerable number of pupils in grades 4, 5, and 6 actually change rooms and teachers during reading periods. The different classes divide into three groups of high, average, and low reading abilities. Fourth-grade pupils of high reading achievement may move to a fifth or even sixth-grade group; the fifth-grade pupils may go into the slower group of fourth-grade or less achievement, stay in their own class, or move up into the group of best readers with sixth grade or better reading ability; sixth-grade pupils may move down one or two classes or stay with the group of best readers. The present investigation evaluates this attempt to provide for individual differences in reading ability by a study of comparable pupil achievement on standardized tests and the opinions of elementary school principals who have had both regular class grouping and inter-class grouping in their school.
References.Comments: ESDE: Use Grade 6 Reading age as post-test only comparing regrouped (homogeneous/ ability group) - intervention with  Remained (heterogeneous/ mixed attainment groups) . NB convert ages to months  - ie 10-11.3 = 131.3 months. Please add label to outcome to make comparison clear (e.g. 'Grade 6 reading Regrouped" and ES should be negative).
References.QuickCitation: Russell David H (1946) Inter-Class Grouping for Reading Instruction in the Intermediate Grades. The Journal of Educational Research 39(6), 462-470 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220671.1946.10881457

References.Title: Effects of Administrator Implemented Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Grouping on Reading Achievement of Selected Sixth-Grade Students
References.Abstract: Problem. A Nation at Risk reported that the average achievement score of high-school students on most standardized tests is lower now than it was a quarter of a century ago, and the majority of the brightest students fail to achieve according to their ability. A salient problem in educating pupils is that of attaining reading comprehension achievement scores comparable to their intellectual potential. This study examines the effects of administrator implemented homogeneous and heterogeneous grouping on the reading achievement of selected sixth-grade students. Method. This was a quasi-experimental study using parametric techniques. The tests for hypotheses were analysis of variance, analysis of covariance, and multiple linear regression. This study compares the reading comprehension achievement of an experimental group and a control group. It also compares the interaction of gender as a factor in reading achievement due to instructional grouping techniques. There were 113 sixth-grade students in the experimental group and 59 students in the control group. Results. Nine hypotheses were tested for three reading group levels: (1) high ability, (2) average ability, and (3) low ability. Reading achievement was not affected to a statistically significant degree at alpha = .05 by either instructional approach--homogeneous or heterogeneous--regardless of reading group ability level. Hypotheses applicable to both high-ability and average-ability students exposed to homogeneous instruction found no significant differences related to gender. However, low-ability female students scored significantly higher than low-ability male students. Hypotheses applicable to both high-ability and low-ability students exposed to heterogeneous instruction found no significant differences related to gender. However, average-ability male students scored significantly better than average-ability female students. Conclusions. Academic performance, as measured by sixth-grade reading scores, was not affected to a statistically significant degree by the instructional approach--homogeneous or heterogeneous--regardless of reading group ability level. Although there was a degree of inconsistency in regard to gender, average-ability male students tended to perform better in reading classes when exposed to heterogeneous instruction and low-ability female students tended to perform better in reading classes when exposed to homogeneous instruction.
References.Comments: This study has 3 different ability groups (high, average,low) and 2 conditions to compare (homogeneous vs. heterogeneous). Please focus in coding homogeneous vs. heterogeneous for high ability.
References.QuickCitation: Thacker Jerry (1987) Effects of Administrator Implemented Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Grouping on Reading Achievement of Selected Sixth-Grade Students. , .

References.Title: Team Teaching and Flexible Grouping in the Junior High-School Social Studies
References.Abstract: Many schools are moving rapidly to make the changes which the schools of tomorrow will require. One of these changes is from the fixed and rigidly involved role of a teacher with a group of students to planned team teaching. Because the junior high school period is one which calls for initial exploration in the understanding and skills leading to effective behavior in a free society, team teaching and flexible grouping seem to be particularly effective methods to use in social studies.
References.Comments: CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is available to download and for checking, it does not display correctly for highlighting.
References.Authors: Zweibelson I ; Bahnmuller M ; Lyman L ;
